metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Bubble Sort with Python
Bubble Sort
Bubble Sort is an algorithm that sorts an array from the lowest value to the highest value.
content.html: Bubble Sort is an algorithm that sorts an array from the lowest value to the highest value.

content.text: Run the simulation to see how it looks like when the Bubble Sort algorithm sorts an array of values. Each value in the array is represented by a column.
content.html: Run the simulation to see how it looks like when the Bubble Sort algorithm sorts an array of values. Each value in the array is represented by a column.

content.text: The word 'Bubble' comes from how this algorithm works, it makes the highest values 'bubble up'.
content.html: The word 'Bubble' comes from how this algorithm works, it makes the highest values 'bubble up'.

content.text: How it works:
content.html: How it works:

content.text: Manual Run Through
Before we implement the Bubble Sort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array only one time, just to get the idea.
content.html: Before we implement the Bubble Sort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array only one time, just to get the idea.

content.text: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.
content.html: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.

content.text: Step 2: We look at the two first values. Does the lowest value come first? Yes, so we don't need to swap them.
content.html: Step 2: We look at the two first values. Does the lowest value come first? Yes, so we don't need to swap them.

content.text: Step 3: Take one step forward and look at values 12 and 9. Does the lowest value come first? No.
content.html: Step 3: Take one step forward and look at values 12 and 9. Does the lowest value come first? No.

content.text: Step 4: So we need to swap them so that 9 comes first.
content.html: Step 4: So we need to swap them so that 9 comes first.

content.text: Step 5: Taking one step forward, looking at 12 and 11.
content.html: Step 5: Taking one step forward, looking at 12 and 11.

content.text: Step 6: We must swap so that 11 comes before 12.
content.html: Step 6: We must swap so that 11 comes before 12.

content.text: Step 7: Looking at 12 and 3, do we need to swap them? Yes.
content.html: Step 7: Looking at 12 and 3, do we need to swap them? Yes.

content.text: Step 8: Swapping 12 and 3 so that 3 comes first.
content.html: Step 8: Swapping 12 and 3 so that 3 comes first.

content.text: Repeat until no more swaps are needed and you will get a sorted array:
content.html: Repeat until no more swaps are needed and you will get a sorted array:

content.text: Implement Bubble Sort in Python
To implement the Bubble Sort algorithm in Python, we need:
content.html: To implement the Bubble Sort algorithm in Python, we need:

content.text: The resulting code looks like this:
content.html: The resulting code looks like this:

content.code_html:
mylist = [64, 34, 25, 12, 22, 11, 90, 5]

n = len(mylist)
for i in range(n-1):
  for j in range(n-i-1):
    if mylist[j] > mylist[j+1]:
      mylist[j], mylist[j+1] = mylist[j+1], mylist[j]

print(mylist)

content.text: Bubble Sort Improvement
The Bubble Sort algorithm can be improved a little bit more.
content.html: The Bubble Sort algorithm can be improved a little bit more.

content.text: Imagine that the array is almost sorted already, with the lowest numbers at the start, like this for example:
content.html: Imagine that the array is almost sorted already, with the lowest numbers at the start, like this for example:

content.code_html: mylist = [7, 3, 9, 12, 11]

content.text: In this case, the array will be sorted after the first run, but the Bubble Sort algorithm will continue to run, without swapping elements, and that is not necessary.
content.html: In this case, the array will be sorted after the first run, but the Bubble Sort algorithm will continue to run, without swapping elements, and that is not necessary.

content.text: If the algorithm goes through the array one time without swapping any values, the array must be finished sorted, and we can stop the algorithm, like this:
content.html: If the algorithm goes through the array one time without swapping any values, the array must be finished sorted, and we can stop the algorithm, like this:

content.code_html:
mylist = [7, 3, 9, 12, 11]

n = len(mylist)
for i in range(n-1):
  swapped = False
  for j in range(n-i-1):
    if mylist[j] > mylist[j+1]:
      mylist[j], mylist[j+1] = mylist[j+1], mylist[j]
      swapped = True
  if not swapped:
    break

print(mylist)

content.text: Bubble Sort Time Complexity
The Bubble Sort algorithm loops through every value in the array, comparing it to the value next to it. So for an array of n n values, there must be n n such comparisons in one loop.
content.html: The Bubble Sort algorithm loops through every value in the array, comparing it to the value next to it. So for an array of nn values, there must be nn such comparisons in one loop.

content.text: And after one loop, the array is looped through again and again n n times.
content.html: And after one loop, the array is looped through again and again nn times.

content.text: This means there are n ⋅ n n ⋅ n comparisons done in total, so the time complexity for Bubble Sort is: O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 )
content.html: This means there are n⋅nn⋅n comparisons done in total, so the time complexity for Bubble Sort is: O(n2)O(n2)

content.text: The graph describing the Bubble Sort time complexity looks like this:
content.html: The graph describing the Bubble Sort time complexity looks like this:

content.text: As you can see, the run time increases really fast when the size of the array is increased.
content.html: As you can see, the run time increases really fast when the size of the array is increased.

content.text: Luckily there are sorting algorithms that are faster than this, like Quicksort , that we will look at later.
content.html: Luckily there are sorting algorithms that are faster than this, like Quicksort, that we will look at later.
